sub_title: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research
summary: My driving force in research is to apply modern and current knowledge in animal health which are instrumental in innovating sustainable solution for livestock production. Currently I am working on several projects to measure host-microbe response influenced by environmental perturbs in livestock species.  My primary goal is to support the 'resilience' of livestock in a sustainable manner that enables them to cope up with the challenges they encounter in their life time.  Meanwhile, my current focus is on gut health and intestinal functionality as influenced by the nutrition and living environment of the animals. My ambition is to apply acquired knowledge, that generate value for projects by inclusion of innovative pipeline and simultaneously gather sound industrial business sense.

treasury_media.title: Developing organoids for livestock research
treasury_media.description: In this project researchers develop organoids to study animal nutrition and health. An organoid is a tiny, simplified version of an organ derived from stem cells. They replicate much of the complexity of an organ and replace some animal experiments.

treasury_media.title: Fly larvae can replace soybean meal in pigs - All About Feed
treasury_media.description: Black soldier fly larvae can replace soybean meal as a protein source in the feed of growing pigs, according to researchers in the Netherlands. Interest

treasury_media.title: Mini-guts as alternative for animal tissue
treasury_media.description: Intestinal organoids or mini-guts can be used as models to evaluate transport and interactions between dietary ingredients with the gut wall. That was discovered by a multidisciplinary research team, led by Prof. Jerry Wells of Animal Science Group,...

treasury_media.title: Improving intestinal health in livestock
treasury_media.description: By infuencing intestinal functionality, animals become more resilient. But what can we do to influence gut health? Research by Wageningen Livestock Research provides answers.

education.field_of_study: Host-Microbe and Interactomics, Animal Science Group

school.name: Master of Veterinary Science programme, State Biotech Hub, Supported by Department of Biotechnology

awards.title: Research Grant: Effects of sanitary and health status on amino acid and energy metabolism of growing-finishing pigs
awards.description: In this project we intend to study the metabolic changes induced by diet composition (both amino acid (AA) level and profile as well as dietary energy source and level) on the response of pigs subjected to a contrast in sanitary status inducing low grade immune stimulation. A global view of the metabolic changes as induced by the sanitary condition and diet composition by analyzing a range of metabolites in blood and saliva using metabolomics platform. Further, we will investigate to what extent saliva (as non-invasive sample type) metabolite-profiles correlate with blood metabolite-profiles. Knowledge and information generated through this project will allow the pig production sector and the feed industry to more precisely match dietary nutrient composition and feeding strategy with the nutritional requirements of pigs under a variety of sanitary and health conditions as encountered in practice.

awards.title: Membership: Impluse Dream Team- Next Level Animal Science Impulse "Complex Cell Systems", WUR
awards.description:
Selected to contribute to the Next Level Animal Science Impulse "Complex Cell Systems": An initiative by the Animal Science Department of Wageningen University & Resarch. 
The task for the "Impulse Dream Team" is to create new innovative methodologies in the area of unravelling mechanismd in complex animal systems from complex data analysis and mechanistic modelling, at all integration levels. bringing first the theoretical ideas into reality.
awards.issuer: Management Team: Animal Science Department of Wageningen University & Resarch.

awards.title: Research Grant: Alternatives to Veterinary ANTImicrobials (AVANT): Co-Applicant
awards.description:
Substitutions of antibiotics in food animals
Antimicrobials such as antibiotics are used to kill or inhibit microorganism growth in human and veterinary medicine. For instance, farmers add antibiotics to animal feed, speeding up their growth and preventing them from getting sick. However, the overuse of antibiotics in farming and agriculture is a growing threat to human health. The EU-funded AVANT project is developing alternatives to antimicrobials for the management of bacterial infections in pigs. These include a gut-stabilising intervention based on symbiotic products and faecal microbiota transplantation, and feed additive products, as well as alternative feeding strategies targeting sows and piglets. Mathematical modelling tools with be used to estimate reduction in antimicrobial use by 2030 if these alternative practices are adopted by the pig production industry.

awards.title: Seed money project grant: Welfare Parent Stock for India
awards.description:
The Top Consortium for Knowledge and Innovation (TKI) coordinates the creation of the Knowledge and Innovation agenda of Top Sector Agri & Food, takes care of the research programme and advises the Top Team Agriculture & Food concerning arrangements with the Minister of Climate and Economic Affairs.

Project detail: 
India is the third-largest egg producer in the world and the fourth-largest chicken producer in the world. Poultry is the most organized sector in animal agriculture in India, worth Euro 14,500 million. Meanwhile, India wants to double its food production in the next decade and naturally the Indian poultry market is laden with opportunities.

However, the poultry sector in India faces multiple major challenges, which in turn could open up opportunities for the Dutch entrepreneurs. For example, low productivity, lack of modern broiler breeder houses, lack of storage, cold chain and transport, lack of supply of quality feed, lack of quality standards in farm management and lack of processing facilities are some of the challenges of poultry secrtor in India that was identified by Rijksdienst voor Ondernemend (RVO) Nederland (2017).

Meanwhile in India, welfare organisations ask for higher welfare state for chicken during production. In this regard cage free housing systems for poultry have proven to be commercially viable particularly in other developed countries including The Netherlands. As India is mostly self-sufficient for chicken production, the government has a leading opportunity to create a humane and level playing field for the chicken industries and legislate for cage free egg and chicken production.

The involved partners in the project have the knowledge and technology to support the transition to more welfare friendly breeder houses in India.

awards.title: Research Grant: Metabolic effects of a high level of dietary zinc in piglet diets to induce immune competence.
awards.description: In this proposal we apply for funds to get access to expertise and facilities which will allow us to study the metabolic changes induced by a high level of dietary zinc, as model intervention, in piglets in the post-weaning period. Combining this knowledge with knowledge gained from transcriptomics on gut tissue and application of metagenomics technologies on intestinal digesta will provide us with a more integrated and complete biological picture of biological processes that underlie growth, productive performance and animal health. This knowledge may contributes to the development of dietary interventions to modify immune competence in livestock.

projects.title: Alternatives to Veterinary ANTimicrobials (AVANT): H2020 EU project
projects.description: Antimicrobials such as antibiotics are used to kill or inhibit microorganism growth in human and veterinary medicine. For instance, farmers add antibiotics to animal feed, speeding up their growth and preventing them from getting sick. However, the overuse of antibiotics in farming and agriculture is a growing threat to human health. The EU-funded AVANT project is developing alternatives to antimicrobials for the management of bacterial infections in pigs. These include a gut-stabilising intervention based on symbiotic products and faecal microbiota transplantation, and feed additive products, as well as alternative feeding strategies targeting sows and piglets. Mathematical modelling tools with be used to estimate reduction in antimicrobial use by 2030 if these alternative practices are adopted by the pig production industry.

projects.title: Effects of sanitary and health status on amino acid and energy metabolism of growing-finishing pigs: Partially funded by ZonMw

Knowledge and information generated through this study will allow the pig production sector and the feed industry to more precisely match diet nutrient composition and feeding strategy with the nutritional requirements of pigs under a variety of sanitary and health conditions as encountered in practice.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: WUR Strategic Themes  “KennisBasis” (KB) funding: Connecting microbiome research at WUR
projects.description:
Circular agro-food production system offers a suitable framework to conduct systematic microbiome research, enabling researchers to study the far-reaching impact of the microbiome and its use as a tool for risk assessments at critical transition points within the food system. 

This framework provides an opportunity for researchers to interrogate and interpret the knowledge and discoveries from the microbiome field. However, it requires appropriate research infrastructure, technologies, data managing tools, strategies, knowledge and relevant expertise from different aspects of the complete chain of the food production system, including plant, soil, livestock, food, human, environment, health, and welfare.

Objective is on one hand is to identify new challenges and cooperation opportunities on microbiome research within Wageningen University & Research (WUR), on the other hand exploring microbiome as a tool in facilitating safe and sustainable food systems in the broadest sense. Further strengthening of microbiome research infrastructures and establishing meaningful collaborations among the relevant stakeholders within WUR comes alongside the trajectory of this initiative.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: Microalgae to improve the health of young animals: PPP
projects.description: The ultimate goal of this PPP is to use innovative techniques, to increase the insight into the functioning of microalgae, so that microalgae can be used effectively to improve the health of young farm animals in particular and to reduce mortality prevent and thereby contribute to the production of sustainable and safe food.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: Rumen microbiome: the variation in methane emmisions in the Dutch dairy herd; funded by the Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality in the context of climate policy.
projects.description: The Livestock & Climate Research examines methane emissions in livestock farming in practice.  In this project we examine variation explained by the rumen microbiome towards methane emmision in the Dutch dairy herd. This research is funded by the Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality in the context of climate policy.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: Impact of feeding seaweed on rumen microbiome of diary cattle
projects.description: Here we wanted to ascertain the effect of dietary seaweeds on rumen microbiome in diary cattle.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: Impact of several nutritional interventions focussing  intestinal microbiome and the subsequent effect on the production, health and welfare of broiler chickens: PPP
projects.description: Impacting Gram-negative bacteria in intestinal and the subsequent effect on the production, health and welfare of broiler chickens with several nutritional interventions.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: Effect of graded levels of microalgae  in the diet on performance and health status of broilers: PPP
projects.description: The outcomes of this experiment can be considered as a stepping stone to increase the utilization of microalgae as ‘functional feed ingredients’ and improve the health of broiler by having a better gut functioning along with stronger immune system, thereby decrease the use of antibiotics in poultry sector.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: Development of metabolite based sensory device to screen livestock performance and health.
projects.description: With this project, we want to explore and thereby discover, phenotype associated, metabolic signatures in biosensor devices developed specifically for livestock.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: MetaPigs: A Danish initiative
projects.description:
The project aims to perform in-depth analysis of the composition and
function of the pig gut microbiota in combination with analyses of host health, genetics and gene regulation identifying modalities securing cost-effective high feed efficiency without a concomitant reduction in beneficial gut bacteria and impairment of the immune system.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: Using intestinal organoids (mini gut) to study feed efficiency: Breed4Food, PPP
projects.description: Organoids provide an excellent in vitro model system to study complex traits which are not easily accessible in vivo. In this pilot study, we want to use organoids to break down the complex trait feed efficiency in well-defined molecular phenotypes.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: WUR Strategic Themes  “KennisBasis” (KB) funding: Organoids
projects.description: Aim of this project is to develop, improve and validate methods to produce and use intestinal organoids of pigs as an in vitro model for testing uptake of, and interactions with, stimulants (like toxins and nutrients) to replace and minimise the use of experimental animals. In line with the ongoing discussion within the society to replace and minimise the use of experimental animals, the developed model and the gathered knowledge could potentially aid relevant stakeholders in animal production (mainly researchers in both public and private sectors engaged in animal breeding, animal nutrition and animal health domain) to continue their efforts towards sustainable animal production system.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: Customized Nutrition: Evaluation of functional properties of current and novel protein sources using enteroids (mini gut).
projects.description: In this project we have investigated the use of intestinal organoids as a model to test the effects of different undigested protein sources on the intestinal epithelium.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: Welfare Parent Stock for India: Funded by Top sector Agri & Food, TKI, The Netherlands
projects.description:
India is the third-largest egg producer in the world and the fourth-largest chicken producer in the world. Poultry is the most organized sector in animal agriculture in India, worth Euro 14,500 million. Meanwhile, India wants to double its food production in the next decade and naturally the Indian poultry market is laden with opportunities.

However, the poultry sector in India faces multiple major challenges, which in turn could open up opportunities for the Dutch entrepreneurs. For example, low productivity, lack of modern broiler breeder houses, lack of storage, cold chain and transport, lack of supply of quality feed, lack of quality standards in farm management and lack of processing facilities are some of the challenges of poultry secrtor in India that was identified by Rijksdienst voor Ondernemend (RVO) Nederland (2017).

Meanwhile in India, welfare organisations ask for higher welfare state for chicken during production. In this regard cage free housing systems for poultry have proven to be commercially viable particularly in other developed countries including The Netherlands. As India is mostly self-sufficient for chicken production, the government has a leading opportunity to create a humane and level playing field for the chicken industries and legislate for cage free egg and chicken production.

The involved partners in the project have the knowledge and technology to support the transition to more welfare friendly breeder houses in India.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: Metabolic effects of a high level of dietary zinc in piglet diets to induce immune competence : Partially funded by ZonMw
projects.description: ZonMw is the Dutch organization for health research and healthcare innovation. ZonMw finances health research and stimulates the use of the developed knowledge - in order to improve care and health. We received financial aid form  ZonMw to get access to expertise and facilities which will allow us to study the metabolic changes induced by a high level of dietary zinc, as model intervention, in piglets in the post-weaning period. Combining this knowledge with knowledge gained from transcriptomics on gut tissue and application of metagenomics technologies on intestinal digesta will provide us with a more integrated and complete biological picture of biological processes that underlie growth, productive performance and animal health. This knowledge may contributes to the development of dietary interventions to modify immune competence in livestock.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: Early life adaptation of broilers to low dietary phosphorus
projects.description: Phosphorus in poultry diet deserves much attention because of its role in birds’ bone and meat development, the excessive P excretion into the environment, high diet costs, and the limited phosphate reserve in the world. Nutritional strategies are being adopted in this project in order to make poultry to better utilize P ensuring an optimal performance, and thus mitigate P pollution.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: Impact of some undesired substances in feed ingredients on health aspects of non-ruminants
projects.description: This report describes the possible toxic effects of some heavy metals and dioxins on health aspects of non-ruminants. Moreover, the contribution of some major feed ingredients and feed phosphates to the supply of heavy metals and dioxin via feed are estimated. It is concluded that the contents of the studied heavy metals in pig and broiler diets usually are far below the levels that might induce toxic effects in these species. In feed phosphates, the contents of arsenic, cadmium, lead, and mercury might be of concern, because they could approach the maximum values as determined by law.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: Evaluation of functional properties of current and novel protein sources in pigs
projects.description: Changes in various local and systemic physiological parameters in pigs were evaluated as induced by diets containing common and new protein sources. Systemic effects were measured by the concentrations of blood cytokines and chemokines along with amine metabolites. The community structure of the small intestinal microbiome and the transcriptional response of intestinal mucosal tissue (jejunum and ileum) served as parameters for the local response.

contributors.headline: Senior Scientist at Wageningen Livestock Research

projects.title: FeedOmics, an approach to evaluate the functional properties of protein containing feed ingredients
projects.description: This thesis presents FeedOmics approach as a toolkit, to evaluate (novel) protein containing feed ingredients of different origin considering both their nutritional and functional value in terms of their capacity to support or modify nutrient supply, the animal’s physiology, tissue development and functioning. Such knowledge may contribute to introduce novel and/or alternative protein containing feed ingredients in the diet of livestock, thus creating a sustainable food supply for growing human population.

profile_positions.description: PhD thesis, entitled “FeedOmics, an approach to evaluate the functional properties of protein containing feed ingredients”, describes “FeedOmics” as multi-omic approach to investigate the nutritional and non-strictly nutritional properties of protein sources with respect to animal physiology, including aspects of immunity, metabolism, and gut health. The research revealed novel biological effects of different protein sources, increasing our understanding of the interplay between nutrition, microbiota and the host. In turn this research has implications for animal production efficiency, which is linked to the increasing demand for animal protein to feed the growing human population.
profile_positions.title: PHD Candidate

company.name: National Research Centre on Pigs, ICAR

profile_positions.company: National Research Centre on Pigs, ICAR
profile_positions.description: In this study we have shown that dietary zinc has an implication at lipid metabolism through its influence on hormonal regulation of adipogenesis and lipogenesis mediated through gene expression of lipogenic enzymes and regulatory factors in grower pigs, hitherto unreported, which might be of significance at the biological, pharmacological and clinical level.
